Alack! The parking lot, at noon, doth cloy,
And, alack! The store, how small it doth appear,
Yet still, my heart doth sing, with love so dear."

"Treasure Island, where's the old pirate show? Now it's just scantily clad performers. Across from Venetian/Palazzo, TI's seen better days. Rooms, casino, food - all mediocre. But hey, if you're looking for a cheap stay on the south end of the Strip, this is your spot. Just don't say I didn't warn you about those pirates."

"Methinks, fair friends, our second year at convention didst bring us to Golden Palace Buffet once more. And lo, didst we find that ordering from menu didst bring us greater joy than buffet of yore. Forsooth, the victuals were not so greasy, and their flavors didst delight our taste buds. Verily, I didst enjoy my meal, and by the looks of it, my comrades didst as well. And note, my large-attired companion didst receive courteous treatment."

"Firm, not soft. That's how I like my tofu. But the tofu here? Soft and squishy. Yellow curry, chunked up into little pieces. No frying, no prep. Just sad. Rich curry, though. Good spice. Veggies, too. Rice, molded into a cone. Nice touch. Lunch menu? Usual Thai stuff. Pad Thai, curries. Small strip mall. High tops by the window, normal tables inside. Empty weekday lunch."

"Pulled over at a Subway on the way back to Vegas from Phoenix. Convenient spot, right off the highway. Ordered a BMT with jalapeno cheddar bread, toasted with all the fixin's. Fresh ingredients, tasted great. Clean restrooms too, a plus. Will stop again next time I'm passing through."

"We hit Vegas, scored a sweet deal at Treasure Island. Checked in, saw the Pho joint, thought it was a joke. Rich folks payin' top dollar for mediocre Vietnamese grub. Next day, we're back, slurpin' noodles, nursin' our hangovers. Pricey? Yeah. But it's Vegas, baby. Worth it? Eh, not the best Pho I've had. But hey, if you're stuck at Treasure Island, give it a shot. It'll fix your hangover, that's for sure."

"Mainland L&Ls just don't taste the same as the ones back home in Hawaii. Food's edible, but bland. And watch out for the prices. Menu board says one thing, but your receipt might tell a different story. Brought it to the worker's attention, and he shrugged it off, saying the computer's got the final say. That's some shady business practice right there."

"Dined with a big group. Host picked a pricey wine, no doubt. Food? Meh. Salad was mediocre, too many beans. Bread and muffins, dry as hell. Duck pancake, drowned in syrup. Couldn't taste the duck. Porterhouse lamb chops, now we're talking. Grilled to perfection, nice sauce. Dessert, some kinda pudding cake. Chocolate, good stuff. Coffee service took forever. Restaurant's nice, but don't get your hopes up."
"Wal-Mart, it don't disappoint. New store, same old vibe. Low prices, standard gear, rowdy crowd. Kids screamin', grannies blockin' aisles, slow drivers on the road. It's your usual Wal-Mart scene."

"This Tesco Superstore serves Leith and Shore residents. Two entrances: one through the Tesco car park, another on Duke Street. It's a typical supermarket, selling groceries, clothes, and electronics. Not the largest, but it gets the job done. Open from 6 am to midnight. Be mindful of the alcohol laws: no sales before 10 am or after 10 pm. Some locals forget this and cause trouble at the checkout. Self-service tills and two fast lane cashiers for baskets only. I don't visit often, post-horse meat scandal. Decent for packaged goods like whisky, spirits, wine, and chocolates. Not the best, but not terrible either."

"Three stars, I give, forsooth,
On decor and atmosphere, they doth excel.
But, alas, the brew, did not impress,
A nonfat chai, it did not please.

Bland, it was, and lacking zest,
No special taste, to make it blessed.
But, the company, was good, I must confess,
And the atmosphere, did please, I must express.

The look of the place, doth strike my fancy,
I shall return, to try their coffee, perchance.
For, the chai, did not meet my expectations,
But, the ambiance, did stir my imagination."

"Not half bad, better than most Scottish fast food. Rootbeer float, though - damn good. Like a taste of home. Burger? Meh, not bad, but lackin' somethin'. Cajun fries, next time. Frozen onion rings? Passable, but not fresh. Now I'm on the hunt for real deal onion rings."

"Hark, I sought a place at center strip,
A lodging fit for royalty, a hop and skip
From Flamingo, where I might have stayed
For just a bit more coin, had I but known
The state of things, the shabby, grimy truth.
But nay, I cannot complain, forsooth,
My chamber had a balcony, a boon,
My sister's suite at Mirage lacked, alack!
The victuals were adequate, naught to crow
About, but neither did they make me sick,
A blessing, that. So, though not a grand
Establishment, 'twas still a step up, mark
From Motel 6, a humble dwelling, plain.
And if thou spend'st too much time within,
Thou dost err, forsooth, and miss the fun."

"Hark, what news is this? A dinner so fine,  
At such a price, it doth astound mine eyes.  
Three courses, wine, and service so bright,  
A bargain indeed, and worth the sight.  
The sardines, oh how they did delight,  
And hake, so flaky, with spinach so green and bright.  
But alas, the cheese board, a slight misstep,  
With oatcakes few, and onion marmalade too thin,  
And brie, so dry, it doth break my heart,  
And knife, with handle broken, doth depart.  
But still, the place, with sunshine so bright,  
Doth make amends, and doth ignite  
My intent, to return once more,  
And taste their fare, as before."

"Coffee joint straight outta 1920s hipster heaven. Dungarees and boots to match, check. Vintage roaster, prominently displayed and well-used, you bet. Craft coffee drought in my town, line out the door, yep. Scored an espresso, efficient service, good but not great, too fruity, not enough chocolatey smoothness, imho. Girl ordered pour-over, waited ten min, forgot, asked, wait another ten, derp. Tasted her cup, delish. Good thing goin', few tweaks needed, I'd return."

"With kin, we dined, in atmosphere snug and warm,
Amidst a Sunday's quiet, almost lifeless storm.
At entry, stench of sewer did our senses greet,
And with disgust, our hopes did quickly retreat.
Yet still, we wished to sample their fair,
Sushi, our love, fifteen times a month we share.
Alas, this place did not meet our standards high,
More akin to market's offerings, did it lie.
Fare was just passable, variety vast,
But oh, how flavors failed, at such cost vast!"

"We caught wind of this joint on Bar Rescue, decided to swing by. Me and the missus rolled in around 9:30 PM. I was famished, figured I'd grab a bite. But the barkeep said the kitchen was shut down due to a slow night. Had one brewski and bailed, couldn't keep drinking on an empty stomach. Next time in Vegas, I'll give this place another go. Maybe more stars too. Locals were cordial, welcomed us with open arms. Bartender was friendly too. Shame I didn't get to try the grub."

"Fair prithee, gentle reader, listen well,
For I have tales to tell of yonder meal,
A feast most wondrous, fit for royalty,
With chicken fried steak, a dish most regal.

Mashed potatoes, fluffy and soft, did grace
The plate, alongside gravy, rich and savory,
Green beans, a verdant delight, did dance
In harmony with the salad, fresh and healthy.

But alas, fair reader, 'twas not all bright,
For coming in, we found no welcome sight,
No host to guide us, lost and confused we stood,
Till one kind soul did bid us take a seat.

Yet, patience, dear reader, for all was not amiss,
For family-owned, this place doth truly bless,
And though the wait, a mite confusing, did last,
The food, a true delight, did make up for the past.

So, prithee, gentle reader, heed my words of cheer,
For though not perfect, this place doth bring us near,
To flavors rich, and family warmth, so dear,
And thus, I say, 'tis worth a visit, come ye near."

"Fare and attendance passable were, my dear. Sweet and sour broth and tofu with babe bok choy, my tastebuds did cheer. \n\nThe ornamentation, grand and elegant, did strike mine eye. Jellyfish lamps, a wondrous sight, and wooden menus, a clever guise."

"A damn fine bar, with prices that won't break the bank. But you know what's missing? A couple more tables, that's what. Two diamond tables, to be exact. And maybe a pool table or two for good measure. That'd make this joint a real hotspot, 24/7. Just saying."

"Standard eatery with decent grub, but nothin' outta the ordinary. A safe bet for a meal, but don't expect anythin' too fancy. Bar's a bit rowdy, hard to hear yerself think, let alone carry on a conversation."

"A well-appointed shop, with wares of yore,
A treasure trove, for all to explore.
But lo, a quibble doth arise,
In matter of the booths, and their surprise.
For none are marked with discounts fair,
To guide the customer, in their quest to share.
And employees, in garb of old,
Do blend with shoppers, unbeknownst to hold.
Their purchases, in newsprint wrappings bound,
A curious choice, for goods renowned.
Thus, room for improvement doth abound,
To elevate the shopping experience profound."

"This joint was alright.  Atmosphere was swell, service top-notch.  Mojito, tasty.  Waffles, too.  Daughter loved the red velvet pancakes.  Price, steep.  Pancakes, thirteen bucks.  Can't afford to come back often."
"Eatery, hip. No reservations, expect delay. Food decent, eggs benedict underwhelming, too hard-boiled. Will try again, excitement tempered."

"Lunchtime found us weary, so we settled in for a bite. Soup, a hearty potato leek, warmed our bellies. My companion opted for tuna on bread, while I chose a simple salad, though a few wilted leaves marred its appeal. Crisp, hot fries accompanied our meals. Dana, our kind server, didn't charge us for the lackluster greens. Her service, however, was truly memorable."

"A pox upon this eatery, wherefore art thou, flavor? 

In fair Los Angeles, I didst savor thy delights, 

But here, alas! thy taste doth falter and deceive. 

The servers, friendly as they may be, cannot make amends 

For dishes lacking zest, and sides that do not flow. 

A Groupon deal, I thought, would ease my woe, 

But lo! the cost, it didst rise, and food, it didst dwindle. 

In brief, a place of sustenance, clean and neat, 

Yet price, it doth not justify, nor doth it meet."

"Upstream's considered top-notch in Charlotte, but I'm from Philly, where the culinary scene's on point. The grub was good, not mind-blowing. Each dish, except the house salad, was oversalted. Hubby had the tuna, I had the seabass. Both solid, but not worth raving about. We'd return for raw stuff, not cooked menu items. The house salad was the real MVP, and the crab bisque was decent too. Service was good, but a tad sluggish. Our waiter was one of the most informed we've met since leaving PA."

"Breakfast joint down the road was slammed. Couldn't find parking. Decided to hit up this new spot instead. Portions were huge. Food was solid. Prices a bit steep, but not enough to keep me away. Ham was off, though. Tasted like it had seen better days. OJ was meh. But they gave us free chocolate-covered strawberries. Those were damn good."

"Airport BBQ, not much to choose from. Decent, not great, but better than the rest. Went with the platter, brisket was fatty, pork was okay, turkey was dry. One sauce option, not mustard-based, but not bad. Healthy sides? Forget about it."

"Hark! My arms do ache with weariness,
As if they'd borne the weight of laughter's cheer.
A comedy club, they say? Nay, nay, my friend,
'Tis but a conference room, transformed, we find.

The staff doth set up chairs, as need doth arise,
And VIP couches, too, for those who prize.
But, truth be told, the space is quaint and small,
No need to pay the extra fee, at all.

Two waitresses, they doth scurry round,
To fill the patrons' orders, profound.
But, alack! The bar, it doth seem,
A better choice, to get thy drink, 'tis seen.

I saw the late show, on a Saturday eve,
Seating starts at 8:30, so arrive, we must, ere then.
But fear not, for there's not a bad seat in sight,
So, sit thee down, and prepare for delight.

Todd Paul, the comedian, he doth shine,
With magic, stunts, and jokes, so fine.
He doth make fun of Las Vegas shows,
And magic, too, his wit doth disclose.

I would return, for another night,
Of laughter and joy, without a fight."

"Ate here a few weeks back. Hotel rec. Steak, not my thing, but friends liked it. Chicken Peppered Penne, that's more like it. Spicy, just how I like. Pasta, cooked right. Sauce, creamy. Flavor, top-notch. Service, good. Prices, reasonable."

"Hark, what Pho have I found in fair Scottsdale? A brew most wondrous, yet in quantity quite meager, and priced so steep! They stint on noodles and meat, as if afraid to fill the bowl. Eight silver pieces paid, and still I leave unsatisfied. Alas, the service here is kind and keen, yet the dish itself doth lack. Give it a try, but heed my words, and ask for more, lest ye depart still hungry."

"Pub's not bad, bit touristy though. Upstairs, grub's good, atmosphere's meh. Downstairs, ale selection's top-notch. Why give out sparkling wine for a business card? Give 'em one of these fine brews or whiskies instead. They keep track of hand-pumped ales too - 1987 last week. That's cool."
"Tax-free, that's the ticket. Off-base, more selection, better deals. But watch out for those lines, they can get nasty. If you're looking to save, take your time."

"Peppermill's got a tacky vibe, but hey, that's part of its charm. The waitresses wear hideous uniforms, like something out of Office Space. We stopped by for breakfast, and it was just alright. The omelets and pancakes were decent, but nothing special. It's a different scene than the Disney-fied buffets on the Strip, that's for sure."
"Beer was decent, not remarkable. Atmosphere was good though. They had a selection of sweet brews, but that's about it. Will give 'em another shot sometime."

"Fly not with this airline, good sir or madam,
If thou art traveling with young ones in tow.
'Tis a no-frills carrier, with naught but the basics,
No television on our five-hour journey, I vow.

The children on board didst grow restless and wild,
Their tiny seats, a prison, their discomfort unild.
The aircraft itself, verily, didst seem quite old,
A relic of days past, its glory long since told.

Delta, then, shall be thy choice, my friend,
For they shall provide a more comfortable end.
With their amenities and spacious seats,
Thy brood shall be pleased, and their tranquility meets."
"Good joint. Solid grub. Great spot to catch a game. Karaoke, thankfully, was MIA. Service? Meh. Understaffed, overwhelmed. Like trying to get a drink at a busy bar. But hey, decent spot overall."

In fair Paris Hotel Casino, there lies a place,
Open twenty-four hours, by the grace.
'Tis a venue of elegance, ambiance refined,
Where food, though naught special, doth suffice.

Desserts, oh sweet delights! Cheap, they be,
For the quantity, a steal, verily.
I, with two others, shared a banana split,
And failed to finish it, alack, a bit.

Ten bucks, or so, the cost, a fair price,
For sugar's delight, in this nice place.
But, alas! The Sugar Factory store,
Overpriced, methinks, its wares, a bore.

Mints, in small tins, five to eight dollars,
A price, too high, for such trifles, fie!
Yet, still, this place, a visit, worth,
For desserts, drinks, and merriment, 'tis birthed.

Fun, it is, with outdoor seats,
A place, to try, at least, on thy feet.

"Fair eatery, with grub most fine,
Eggs upon top, a wondrous sight divine.
Tortillas of blue corn, sturdy and thick,
Enchiladas savory, a true delight quick.
Margaritas, alas, a bitter draught,
Sour and weak, with naught but a faint draft.
Salsa, too, lacked zest and verve,
Average fare, with naught to preserve.
Yet still, a score of eight, I give,
For value fair, and atmosphere alive."

"Upon our visit to Fiesta Mall, my son and I didst partake in a meal. Our hunger sated, we wandered 'round the food court, whereupon an employee of Sarku Japan didst offer us samples of their teriyaki chicken. My son, enticed by the flavor, didst decide to order from thence. The staff were friendly, and the price was fair. He chose the teriyaki chicken and shrimp, and the portion was greater than we didst expect. The taste was true to its name, and my son didst express his satisfaction. A place we shall visit again, and highly recommend!"

Maria, our host, didst roll her eyes and bear a haughty mien,
As if her duties were a burden, and her guests a plight.
But Kyahl, a man named Kyle, didst answer questions with grace,
And showed a willingness to help, with a gentle face.

The victuals, alas, were not all of equal worth,
For while the veal parmesan didst please, the macaroni rosa didst not.
The broccoli within was raw, and the pasta, overcooked,
Leaving us to wonder if the chef had been beset by some ill luck.

"Decent grub, but nothing special. Been here a few times, always for events. Good Indian food, but not spectacular. Meat could be better quality, same with the ingredients. Salads lacked greenery, korma and tikka had small portions. Felt like they were cutting corners. Desserts were average, gulab jamun and jelebi are my weaknesses, but they didn't have much. Not the best in AZ, India Gate might be better. Try that first."

"Aw hell, I gotta say this place ain't all that. I mean, I loved their other spot up north, but this one's missin' somethin'. I had the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos, and let me tell ya, they just didn't taste the same as the other place. The ceviche was too fishy, needed more lemon and salt, and the tacos were just plain ol' boring. Nice restaurant, good service, but the food just wasn't up to par. Not worth the higher prices, especially when you can get a better experience elsewhere. Give 'em three stars for potential, but I won't be comin' back."

"Hark! A pizza white as snow didst I order,
With tomato, onion, and olive so fair.
'Twas tasty indeed, but the crust, alas!
Was burned by the wet ingredients' kiss.
The staff within were plenty and fine,
But the price, oh! It didst lack value divine.
I shall not return, forsooth, too far away,
And other places shall have my coin ere they."

"A vast expanse, this place did seem,
With bar in center, grand and serene.
Menu, of high estate, it did boast,
Yet, draft beer, a scarcity, at most.

Fare, was pleasant, I must confess,
But, alas, no brew, of finest impress.
Televisions, many, they did possess,
Yet, charm, of old, did lack, I must profess.

Too commercial, this place did feel,
For one who seeks, a tavern, real."

"Amidst the sprawling complex of Caesars Palace,
A curious lodging lies, a hotel within a hotel,
With shorter check-in lines, a welcome reprieve,
And Asian-themed chambers, a unique appeal.

But alas, dear traveler, do not be deceived,
For though the rooms may boast a novel theme,
The service here is lacking, slow and meek,
A far cry from the luxury of a five-star dream.

In truth, Caesars Palace, once grand and proud,
Now falters, weighed down by age and neglect,
While Wynn, Bellagio, and Venetian, stand tall,
Superior choices, for those who crave excellence.

So if thou seekest comfort, and service true,
Look elsewhere, fair guest, for this place doth not suffice,
But if thou art content with mediocrity,
Then perhaps, this humble hotel within a hotel, shall suffice."

"Joe's place, been there a few times. Good grub, no doubt. Service? Forget about it. Terrible, every damn time. But hey, the atmosphere's fun, so it's worth a shot. Just don't expect too much from the help, you hear me?"

"A fine array of brew, my friend,
A veritable cornucopia, at thy behest.
The victuals, middling fare, yet naught to scorn,
For 'tis the usual bar-grub, no more, no less.
The servers, kindly folk, with smiles so bright,
And barkeeps, skilled in their art, a wondrous sight.
A spacious hall, to hold the throngs of men,
Worth stopping by, ere thou dost wend thy way again."

I went out with my guy last night and we had a great time at this joint. The patio was top-notch, nice view, quiet, and secluded even though it's right above Indian School Road. They got a killer wine and beer selection, lots of local options too. Food was alright, not amazing though. Started with some solid fries, had rosemary and parmesan, and a decent dipping sauce. Pizza was pretty good, had some caramelized onions, mushrooms, Italian sausage, and a good crust. Not too crispy, not too soft, but you definitely need a fork and knife for it. Ragu was different, kinda like a shredded beef burrito but in a bowl with penne pasta instead of a tortilla. Wasn't terrible, just unexpected. Wished we tried dessert, they looked great. All in all, this spot is good for apps and drinks, especially on that sweet patio.

"Fair coffee, by my troth, I do confess,
Thou art a beverage most excellent,
But now, alas, I must thy virtues dismiss,
For doughnuts and bagels, they do tempt me still.
Ask me again, when forty pounds be gone,
And then, perchance, my taste buds shall be won."

Yester-e'en, with friends, I didst venture hither,
To partake in breakfast fare, and quaff a bit o' brew.
Upon mine entrance, I didst note the scent so sweet,
And eagerly anticipated their waffles, oh so neat.

We sat and pondered o'er the menu, a good long while,
But nary a soul didst check on us, or offer a smile.
At last, we made our choices, and to the counter didst go,
To order our repast, with haste, and no small show.

The lass behind the counter, didst interrupt mine friend,
As he began to order, with a shout, so unbecoming, I didst frown.
Our victuals took a while, but when they arrived,
They looked most fair and tempting, our hunger to assuage.

What we didst order, I shall now recount,
A red velvet wafflenut, a Nutella and almond wafflenut,
The Fat Elvis waffle, a strawberry and chocolate waffle,
And a Vegas churro waffle, with honey, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla ice cream, so cool.

All was well, the churro waffle, our favorite, by far,
And I, myself, didst enjoy the strawberry waffle, sans the chocolate sauce, so tar.
The service, alack, didst leave much to be desired,
And the location, awkward, so I fear, my return, unlikely, to be required.
"Fast service, but overpriced eats. Inn n Out's still tops for a quick burger fix. Bachi Burger's the real deal for gourmet bites in Vegas."
"Tourist trap, long waits. Pricey too. Crispy duck on noodles, damn good. But not big enough. Portions small, prices high. That's my gripe with LOS. Lost two stars for that."

"Wife drug me in here after she had their surf 'n turf. Said it was top-notch. Can't say yet.
Sat at the bar, played some poker. Not a big deal, but they make you bet big for a second drink. Nice enough to warn me, still comped my drink. Maybe that's why we were the only ones playin'.
Ordered some grub, sat at a table, brought our drinks over. Portions were big, philly's great. But wait 'til you see the bill. Saw the prices, but by the time we finished eatin', tip included, it was near forty bucks for two sandwiches. Didn't even have any drinks to pay for.
Good stuff, but I just don't see the draw for a sandwich joint like this. Prices are steep."

"Our engagement feast, a merry gathering 'twas,
With family, at this place, we did convene.
A busy night, on Wednesday, it did fall,
And parking, alack, was scarce, to hear them call.
The door, it opened wide, with gusts of cold,
And smoke, it did imbue, our nostrils bold.
A cramped corner, we did occupy,
My siblings small, in chairs, did sit so nigh.
Lobster, trout, flounder, chicken, beef, and greens,
A feast, it was, but naught, our taste, it teased.
One order, mistaken, a frown did cause,
But grandam's pleasure, my heart, it did enthrall.
This place, again, I may, with joy, revisit,
If not by door, in winter's bitter blast, I sit."

"Paul Martin's: classy joint, shame about the periphery. 

DC-style steakhouse with pleasant lighting, music, and vibes. Food's good too. Had the Sunday special: salad, prime rib, ice cream for $25. Salad was decent, prime rib had a killer spice rub, but the interior was meh. No lactose-free dessert options, which sucked. 

Service was lacking. Server seemed overwhelmed, gave us weird looks for using a gift card. Four stars for the grub, two for the service. Three stars overall."

"Methinks the staff doth strive to be most kind,
Their aid, a gentle breeze upon my mind.
Tidiness doth reign supreme, a wondrous sight,
Yet, alack, a dearth of choices doth impinge on delight."

"Uncle Bears, a joint where you can grab a bite, a brew, and shoot some stick. Menu's alright, nothing fancy but the sliders are solid. Chicken fajitas are good too, don't believe the rubber talk. Beer selection's top-notch, local and national. Decor's cool, lots of pup pics. Good spot for a chill night out."

"D'Arcy McGee's doth serve a medley of dishes,
Of Anglo-Saxon origin, in truth it doth seem.
From Irish boxty to corned beef and cabbage,
Scotch eggs and Canadian poutine, a feast most lavish.
And British Yorkshire pudding, a treat for the taste,
Portions are generous, service with a smile, most grace.
The victuals themselves, middling in quality, I say,
But a refreshing change from the usual fare, in sooth.
For those who tire of wings, pizza, or sandwiches,
D'Arcy McGee's doth offer a new and pleasant experience."

"Pho, a dish most wondrous, yet not the best,
In Pittsburgh's realm, there be better, at least.
No egg rolls, alas, with lettuce and herbs, they do not serve,
But the owner, a man of warmth and grace, doth preserve.
A smile on his face, a kind word on his tongue,
Doth make amends for the lacking, and maketh it not so wrong."

"Marble Slab Creamery, in Stonecrest Shopping Center, near JoJo's and Dean & Deluca. Standard ice cream joint. Decent flavor selection, including Ice Cream Cupcakes, whole cakes in a stand-up freezer. Few chairs and tables, but outdoor seating by the big fountain. \n\nTried an Ice Cream Cupcake, fine. Bought a Birthday Cake milkshake, not blended well, sweet milk then ice cream clumps. Employees friendly. Not impressed, but didn't expect to be. A-OK."
"Tucked near the outlet, this spot's a breeze to find. They got free packin' tape too, no need to buy it like at them other joints. Friendly staff, not like them grumpy USPS folks."

"We swung by for a drink and dessert before catching a flick. Sat on the patio, just us two. Service was good despite the emptiness. I had a frozen 'rita, a tad watery, but my man's Victoria beer was decent. Ordered vanilla ice cream, presentation was neat, enjoyed the crispy goodness. Hit the ladies' room before heading out, big mirror, clean, spacious. Might go back for dinner next time."

"A 25-footer didst thou rent, my friend?
With troubles electrical, it didst descend.
Three times in ten days, alas! didst break,
And each time, help didst come, for thy sake.
Their staff, with haste, didst send a man,
To parks afar, to fix the plan.
But lo! The rig, before, hadst been ill-serviced,
And thus, the problem, still didst persist.
A disappointment, it didst bring,
But once the battery, didst thou fling,
Our journey, quite good, didst become,
And thus, I wouldst rent, anew,
But with a newer coach, I wouldst choose,
And verify, its state, with more news."

"Fairview Grill didst provide a merry eve,
With grub and ale, and atmosphere quite free.
A coupon, bless thee, didst grant us a boon,
And prices, verily, didst seem most reasonable.

Burgers, thy fare, didst please our taste,
And fries, and onion rings, didst grace the plate.
Our server, kind and attentive, didst attend,
Without a scribe, our order didst she comprehend.

The tavern's mood, didst strike a chord,
Of friendliness, and mirth, and laughter unrestrained.
Two gentlemen, with waves and words of cheer,
Didst greet us warmly, and didst dispel all fear.

Aye, Fairview Grill, thou art a place most dear,
Where we shall return, and revel in good cheer.
Perhaps, a game of pool, shall be our next quest,
At this, thy humble abode, where we found such rest."

"Hiltonâ€™s good. Staffâ€™s great. Locationâ€™s meh, but roomâ€™s nice. Buildingâ€™s nice too. Timeshare presentation? Avoid it. Not worth the bad taste. If youâ€™re an owner, sure, good place to stay. But if you hate high-pressure sales crap, skip it. Not worth it."

"Methinks I do enjoy this place,
Where music doth play and laughter doth grace.
The victuals, they did please my taste,
But, alas! The service, slow as molasses in winter's chill embrace.
A platter of chips, most delectable, did take an hour to arrive,
And though they were worth the wait, 'twas a trying test of patience, I do confess.
Yet, praise be for the ale, a fine selection on tap,
Mayhap with time, the service shall improve, and all shall be well."

"Alack, I must confess, my expectations were not met,
The victuals, verily, were of excellent taste,
But alas, the service, it did not befit,
My appetizer, ere it was devoured, didst come to haste,
And the sweet treat, a disappointment, alack,
I didst anticipate a lengthy, luxurious repast,
But nay, 'twas not to be, for I didst feel the hasty pace,
And thus, my friends, the cost, it didst not merit,
Forsooth, a letdown, this dining experience didst prove to be."
"Decent paper, good access to writers. Location's top-notch, right next to my office. Convenient for errands, you know? Makes a damn fine fire starter too."

"A merry eve I didst spend in this bustling Portuguese tavern,
Where the atmosphere was jolly, and the kitchen a sight to behold.
The crowd was hip and well-to-do, and the fare was good and plentiful,
But alas, the cost was high, and my purse didst feel the pinch.

For tapas, mains, desserts, and drinks, the price didst mount,
And soon, my bill didst reach a sum most considerable and grand.
The seafood dishes, though tasty, didst come at a steep cost,
Near forty pieces of silver, a price most prohibitive, no doubt.

So, if thou hast the means, then by all means, do indulge,
But if thy purse is lean, then best to avoid, or be prepared to budge.
For though the evening was enjoyable, the cost didst leave a sour taste,
And I, a humble playwright, must needs be mindful of my finances, in haste."

Hark! A traveler, new to this Hampton Inn's halls,
Finds familiar setup, yet staff most fair and bright.
Arriving ere three, they didst grant me a room straightway,
Clean and tidy, naught to dismay.

Off to the Fitness Center, in late afternoon's glow,
A closet, mislabeled, didst my hopes doth blow.
Small space, scant equipment, and scarce room for four,
Disappointment doth abound, alack and alas!

"Twas a plain dish, I must confess,  
The lamb entree, with naught but legumes dressed.  
Alack, the flavor! None couldst be found,  
No rosemary, nor any herb of renown.  
'Twas British fare, in truth, I swear,  
Plain as the day, without a hint of cheer.  
The service, too, didst leave much to be desired,  
Our waiter, nice, but dishes uninspired.  
One server brought them, and we had to shift,  
To make space, forsooth, a sorry plight.  
In sooth, we expected more, I do declare,  
From those who served, with skill and care."

In department stores, chaos doth reign supreme,
A space most vexing, full of noise and gleam.
But during holidays, a strange sight doth unfold,
A spectacle most curious, worth behold.

The display, with urgency and zeal,
Doth take on new importance, doth reveal.
A sick fascination, some may call it,
But I, in midst of crowd, didst find a thrill.

Amidst the multitude, I didst roam,
My brother, searching for a gift, didst follow.
Perfume section vast, endless it seemed,
Each aisle attended by a charm, a beauty unmatched.

Cher-endorsed scents, they didst proffer,
Spritzing faces, with nary a thought or tether.
Hellish, yet hypnotic, the scene didst play,
A strange delight, in midst of holiday fray.

"I'm a man who likes to have a good time, and I usually do. Went with a group of about 30, so it was a wild scene. But for some reason, I just wasn't feeling this place. Yeah, it had all the usual strip club stuff - cute girls, hot ladies, expensive drinks. But strip clubs are like masturbation - they seem like a great idea at first, but after a few minutes, you realize you've just screwed yourself. +1 star for that cute stripper who chatted with me and took me to a quiet spot, not trying to take all my money."

"Fair fare, atmosphere, and decor, I pray thee, good sir, yet mark thou well, the service here, how inhospitable and lame! 'Tis a sorry state of affairs, I do declare, and one that doth bespeak a lack of management, a poor regard for guests, and little care for their comfort or their time. Prepare thyself, then, to wait, and wait, and wait, ere thy needs be met, and mayhap, just mayhap, thou shalt find thyself rewarded with a meal most fair and fine."

"Saturday night, I went to see Billy Gardell. Knew I'd get screwed, but still. Pros: great acts, intimate setting, reasonable tickets, parking validation, decent grub at fair prices, friendly service. Cons: packed like sardines, insane drink prices, forced to buy two drinks, food doesn't count towards minimum, mandatory tip. Won't be back 'til they change their ways or a comic I really want to see comes around. They're in it for the cash, but they can go to hell for being greedy and ruining comedy theaters."

"Methinks my friends do hold this place in high esteem,
But I, myself, didst find it merely passable, methinks.
'Tis true, the style of pizza one doth prefer,
Doth play a crucial role in one's overall verdict.

I, personally, do crave a pizza rich in sauce,
For that, to me, doth make the pizza truly worthy.
Alas, the pies here lacked that certain je ne sais quoi,
That certain something that doth set my heart aglow.

The crust, I must confess, was quite well-done,
But, alack, the sauce and cheese were scant, ere gone.
Now, I, a man of taste, do hail from Chicago's streets,
Where pizza places doth abound, and each doth vie for seats.

In Phoenix, too, they say there be some fine establishments,
But, alas, I find them but mediocre, at best, in their presentations.
Ah, Lou Malnattis, Giordano's, how I miss thee,
Thy pizzas, they do rival those of Italy, I swear!"

"Hark! What place is this? 'Tis Carowinds, a park of delight,
With rides aplenty, to bring joy to thy sight.
And though some be surrounded by games and such,
The children, they shall have their fun, no doubt.
The folk, they be kind and welcoming, indeed,
Their hospitality, a true virtue doth proceed.
A feast for thee, with brisket and chicken so fine,
Thou shalt feel welcome, and in merriment doth dine."
"Came here on the 24-hour buffet pass. Not as good as Wynn's, but not bad either. Inviting interior. Line's a bitch, unless you're diamond or platinum."

"Tamale chx salad and raspberry tea. Chx salad, good. Grapes, celery, green onion, almonds, sliced thin. Not overpowering. Tamale, not bad. Not dry, somewhat flavorful. Out of strawberry honey tea. Settled for raspberry. Typical. Meal, $8. Not bad. Won't be back. Except for strawberry-honey tea. Friendly and fast."

"Alas, we did arrive too late, my friends,
And were told straight away, ere we could sit,
That all the seats were taken, and naught remained
But take-out orders, which we gladly did obtain.

Our hunger sated, we didst devour the fare
With gusto, and found it to be quite fair.
Garlic aioli, a sauce most wondrous, didst grace
My pasta dish, and made it all the more delicious.

A salad, fresh and crisp, didst also please,
And Adam Wilcox, the manager, didst appease
Our special requests, with a smile so bright.

And lo, they do offer gluten-free dishes,
So order them specifically, lest ye miss
These options, which may save thee from woe."

"Had a killer burger at the P-stone. No frills, just like mom used to make. Paired it with a few cold ones, and it hit the spot. Place has a chill vibe, not too rowdy. Regulars are friendly, feels like home. Perfect spot for a low-key night out with pals."

In days of yore, I chanced upon this place,
A dive, they call it, with a humble face.
'Twas once known as Chaser's, now renamed,
Fu Manchu, the band, not the film, aroused my claim.

In this strip mall, on Hayden and Roosevelt's corner,
I saw some local bands, their talent did unfold,
Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave, their names did echo,
The latter, a punk band, with members old as the ages flow.

The bar, unchanged, still holds its charm,
A crowd, it drew, like bees to honey in the farm.
Through throngs, I pushed, to reach my destination,
The men's room, lacking a door, a curious sensation.

A gin and tonic, I ordered, with a twist,
But found it weak, my thirst, it did not quench, nor lift.
The headliners, oh, how loud they played,
My ears, they rang, as if the bells of Notre Dame had swayed.

I'd return, but only for a show,
For this place, alas, is not my go-to, you know.

In sooth, fair traveler, this inn of rest,
A place of solace for weary breast,
Thou get'st what thou dost pay, 'tis true,
A humble abode, yet clean and new.

The service, kind; the chamber, neat,
The bath, a place to wash thy feet,
And shuttle, too, doth take thee thither,
To Strip's great mall, and airport's tether.

All needs were met, no want didst stay,
Thus, content, I passed the night away.
A decent lodging, fair and bright,
In pricey Vegas, a wondrous sight.
"Good people, odd trinkets. Quality's been solid, fresh produce. Dried fruit and nuts, that's my jam."

"Muddled cocktail, a sublime delight,
Friendly service, with attendance most bright.
A varied menu, with options to suit all purses,
In a grand setting, with modern decor, a true pleasure.

But alas, the food, a disappointment, I fear,
For though the menu boasts, the dishes do not appear.
Stylized choices, indeed, yet lacking in substance,
Leaving one to ponder, the true essence."

"Methinks we sought to dine at Julian Serrano's halls,
For their ceviche and tapas did our hearts enthrall.
I, for one, didst order the mixed seafood ceviche,
But alas, 'twas naught but mediocrity that didst greet mine eyes.
The steamed mussels, though, didst please mine taste,
But the spare ribs and mushroom risotto, alack, didst fail to amaze.
A pox upon the cook, for his dishes didst lack
The flair and finesse that doth make a meal most wondrous and grand."

"Tis well, my friend, I pray thee tell me true,
What dost thou think of yonder chicken pita?
Aye, 'twas a tasty treat, the pita bread was fine,
But, prithee, more of that cucumber sauce divine!
The chicken, verily, was thick and plentiful,
Worth every penny, I doth declare, anon.
Yet, methinks, a little something extra wouldst make,
This humble meal, a feast most wondrous and great.
But fear not, good sir, for there be many a place,
Where thou mayst find a meal to suit thy taste."

"Beware, fair maiden, for they do employ lean meat within their culinary creations! Haha, I doth jest, yet verily, the patty was somewhat parched. A decent repast, nonetheless, with two such patties and a sharing of fried potatoes. The total sum demanded of us? Thirty silverlings, a paltry sum, indeed. Alas, methinks we shall not return."
"Two bucks for a latte, any size.  Small, medium, large - doesn't matter.  All cost the same, two dollars.  Wednesdays only.  That's the deal."

"Average joint. Nothing special. Good grub, decent atmosphere. Didn't knock my socks off, but maybe that's 'cause I didn't try their signature pizza. Will update next time I'm in the area, if I feel like going back. Recommend it for big groups looking for cold beers and pub grub while catching a game."

"Hark! This humble abode of fried delights doth please,
In Charlotte's Southend, a local treasure 'twill seize.
The crowds gather early, by eleven o'clock,
And stay until the day's end, or till the food doth lock.
Cash only, they accept, so prepare thy purse,
And fear not the folk gathered round, 'tis but a verse.
Quickly thou shalt order, and receive thy feast,
Then make haste, for others wait, their turn to seize.
Fried chicken, fish, and more, a menu most fair,
But for me, the chicken, all day, without compare.
Add hush puppies, slaw, and thy day shall be bright,
Go, visit this place, and taste their delight."

"Recovering from food poisoning, I didn't bother with the menu. My boyfriend, on the other hand, raved about the spicy pork tacos. Said they were the best he'd ever had. Place was packed, lines out the door. Gave it five stars, no question. \n\nBut is it worth the wait? That's the question. Fifty minutes, minimum. Six lines, confusion everywhere. Pork, offal, beef - all separate lines. One guy, doing two jobs. Making tacos like a machine, but still, takes forever. And all those to-go orders? More work for the poor bastard. Needs a better system, that's for sure."

"Classy joint, plenty of room to breathe. Good mix of games, grub, and shops. Service is A1, restaurants cater to all tastes, including vegan and veggie options. Parking's a breeze, casino's cozy, not cramped."

"A platter of popcorn with bacon didst we partake,
And found it to be but mediocre fare.
The chicken and waffles, a dish most strange,
We didst share, but found it not to our liking, I do declare.
For though the ribs were tender and tasty,
The greens that came with them were naught but nasty.
So if thou dost decide to dine at this place,
Pray heed my words and arrive ere the crowd doth race."

"This joint was decent, not too shabby but nothing special. Food was just okay. We came for the beef noodle soup, but it didn't impress. Overpriced, but we got comped so I can't gripe. Had to pay, I'd be pissed. Got the Hainan Chicken Rice, dry as hell. Beef Chow fun was meh. Best part was the iced coffee, six bucks though. Fried Shrimp Balls were good, but the Soupy Dumplings were a letdown. Most dishes were just average. Won't be back."
"Burritos at Taco Bell, nothing fancy. Bean and 7 Layer, my go-to. Order was spot on, place was tidy, food was alright. Not much to rave about, but I'll be back."
"Valentine's Day, pre-fixed menu. Overpriced, of course. Food was mediocre, bulk cooking. Small portions, couldn't finish. Hunger persisted. View from the window, incredible."

"Hark, what airport is this? 'Tis one of revelry and mirth,
Where gambling dens beckon, ere thou hast collected thy earthly wealth.
A place of merriment, where joys doth abound,
And baggage claims do double duty, as slot machines are found.

But fear not, fair traveler, for this airport doth move with haste,
Efficient in its ways, it doth deliver thee to thy destination with speed and grace.
So let us raise a glass, and give thanks to this wondrous place,
For it doth bring us joy, and doth unite us in our revelry and cheer."

"No EPL ticket? What kind of English bar doesn't show Arsenal vs Chelsea? Hang the flags and scarves, but no game? Not a good look, mate. Great beer selection, nice decor, but what's the point without the football? Not impressed."

"Took my PS3 in, twice, still busted.  Refund, no charge.  Good policy, good service.  But, they took my unplayed GTA 5, put it in a ziplock.  Disc looked like hell.  Came back twice, like a virgin.  Not sure 'bout takin' anything else there."

"Went to Tutti Santi in Phoenix for a business meet. Co-worker's father-in-law suggested it. Busy night, promo or somethin'. Took a while to order. Got a bottle of wine, salad, gnocchi. Bread was good. First bottle emptied before food came. Ordered another. Gnocchi was good. Second bottle never came. Waiter apologized, but that was it. Woulda been four stars, but service was off."

"Four of us, waiting 20+ minutes on a Thursday night. No bar to pass the time, no buzzer to signal our table was ready. But when we finally sat down, the food was good. Burgers with plenty of toppings. Not remarkable, but satisfying. A decent meal at Harrah's."

"Methinks 'tis not the task of yonder cinema hall  
To bear the burden of thy littered refuse.  
Forsooth, 'tis thine own duty to rid thee  
Of rubbish bought, and thus, dispose of it thou must.  
Didst thy dam not school thee in tidiness?  
Or art thou of the mind that others shall  
Bear the weight of thy neglectfulness?  
Fie upon such thoughts! Take heed, good sir,  
And heed my words, for they are wise guiding principles."

"Applebee's usually hits the spot with decent grub at a fair price. This particular joint wasn't half bad, but nothing to write home about either. 

We were sat quick, but service slowed down after that. Our waitress messed up the beer order for one of my buddies, took her time bringing the right one, and then dragged her feet on extra napkins. 

I went with the lunch special - half a sandwich and a small salad. The shrimp and spinach salad was solid. The California turkey club was a letdown though. The lettuce was sour as hell, so I picked it all off. The bread was too greasy too. 

The sangria was pretty damn good, but could've used more fruit."

"Verily, I have visited this place before, 'tis a tiny village, full of shops and stalls. They doth play music, alive and loud, in the evening hours. But alas, the atmosphere doth not agree with me, 'tis a place for families, and I didst feel most awkward. My date and I, we didst seek other pursuits, for this place, it doth not suit my tastes. Mayhap, one day, I shall return, but not in the near future, that is certain."
"Overpriced, that's what it is. Good grub, sure, but not worth the coin they're askin' for it. You get a decent-sized portion, but that don't make up for the cost."

"I wanna like this joint. It's near my digs, the cupcakes look tasty, and it smells great. Been here twice, and they got some wild flavors - Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, Peanut Butter and Honey. Who comes up with that?

Thing is, maybe I hit it at the wrong time. Cake was good, but the frosting was too much. Even for my husband, Mr. Brownie-Eating-Champion. He had to scrape it off halfway through. Too rich for his blood.

But I ain't giving up. Gonna try again 'cause I got a thing for cupcakes. Had 'em at our wedding, even. So, I'll be back."

What's the fuss, my friends? They say this be  
The finest Buffett of all, but pray tell,  
I do not see it. Nay, I do not think  
This feast doth stand above the rest, no way.  
Breakfast, thou art far superior, 'tis true,  
To dinner, with the same dishes anew.  
Ha! Laughable indeed, methinks, good sirs.

"Hark! I shall begin with this remark,
The Midnight Diner, a place most fair and bright,
In Charlotte, a staple, a beacon in the night.
But alas, my friends, my experience tonight,
Did not reflect the excellence I had in sight.
Ashley, our server, with a frown so dire,
Refused to change my order, with nary a smile or fire.
And thus, the service we received, was quite poor,
Leaving us feeling stereotyped, and somewhat sour.
But fear not, dear friends, for all was not lost,
For Larry, a server with a noble cost,
A.k.a. 'Showtime', with a grin so wide,
Didst salvage what remained of our evening's tide.
He, with his excellent service, didst shine so bright,
A true prototype of what good service doth ignite.
And though our server, Ashley, didst receive no tip,
Mayhap she shall learn from her peers, and make a shift.
So, shall I return, with hopes to see,
'Showtime' once again, and his service, so divine and free."

"In Vegas, I spend 20 bucks on a Subway five-dollar footlong. What a joke. But seriously, how is it legal for them to rip us off like that? Slots of Fun is like a 20-ton boulder going downhill, unstoppable once it gets going. I don't even gamble here. When I stay at Riviera, I come over to Slots of Fun for a Nathan's hot dog or an overpriced Subway sandwich. There's something I like about the place. It's old-school Vegas. Vegas needs more places like this. Hate to say it, but I'll be back."

"In the Carolinas, my husband and I got a surprise. First meal, and we didn't know what to expect. Plastic tablecloths and not much atmosphere, but we stayed and ate. Looking for a California wrap, but they had southern fried chicken, skillet fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens... and BBQ. What is BBQ? Sauce? Pork? Beef? Chicken? No idea. Ordered from their big menu, lots of fried veggies. Note to North Carolina: food can taste good without being fried. Waitress was nice, yes ma'am, sweet as pie. Hoping to find a place with more variety than sandwiches, southern cooking, and unhealthy veggies."

"A fair location for a meal most decent,
Ere the game doth start, and crowds do gather.
Though 'tis busy, fare and service be neat,
Alas, the price doth rise, a penny-pincher's bane."

"This joint's alright for a Vietnamese spot. Walked in, thought it smelled like cigars. Turns out it was the cigar bar next door. Service was quick, the owner was friendly and gave good recs. Food came out fast. Had the beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls, BF got chicken pho. Also got Vietnamese iced coffee. Loved the broth, not too greasy, could taste the herbs. Rice noodles were meh, a bit too starchy. Eye round steak was a bit overcooked. Iced coffee was too sweet, too much condensed milk. Decent experience, will prob come back. Side note: if you like spicy, ask for ot satay sauce. It's Thai chilies fried with garlic paste, it's hot - a better alternative to sriracha, in my book."

"This joint? Love it. Drinks, top-notch. Prices, reasonable. G Spot, martini, both good choices. Food, damn good too. Fez burger, don't know what's on it, but it's freaking delicious. Three stars though? Got sick after. Can't pinpoint the cause, but now I'm hesitant to return."

"Hark! What news is this? A Zagat list doth crown the best steak of chain restaurants. Pray tell, what folly is this? Shall we compare the growth of grass, and judge which blade doth reign supreme? No, for such things are not meant to be judged. Forsooth, chain restaurants, by their very nature, do serve steak that doth leave much to be desired. Yet, Outback, a place of wonder, doth offer a shrimp appetizer, served upon a bed of golden brown bread, that doth rival the gods. And, oh! The cheese fries, with bacon and ranch, doth make thy arteries tremble with fear. 'Tis a feast fit for the gods, and worth the journey. But, alas, steak, thou art not found here. Save thy search, fair traveler, and seek not the impossible dream."

"A most excellent tavern, full of cheer and delight! The atmosphere doth please mine eyes, and the company, most agreeable. The decor, a lounge style, doth bring forth thoughts of merriment and joy. The drinks, aplenty, doth flow with haste, and the taste, most satisfying. A vodka grey goose, with tonic, doth fill mine glass, and my comrade's, a rum and diet coke, doth quench his thirst. The pricing, fair and reasonable, doth make mine purse sing with glee. The serving maidens, attired in lacy finery, doth attend to our needs with grace and charm. In sooth, a most enjoyable experience, fit for a king!"

"Capriotti's. Good sandwiches, but not all connect. Capastrami, greasy pastrami, Swiss, cole slaw, Russian dressing. Reubenesque. Bread holds up. Cheesesteaks, Italian subs, dense bread, no flavor. Meat, grisly, dry, bland. Bobbie, mayo, gross. Turkey, good on cold subs, provolone, hot peppers. Jersey Mike's, better cold subs. Pop's, cheesesteaks, Vegas."

"Went to this joint with a bunch of friends, had to wait a bit. Small place, real trendy, so expect a delay. Red velvet pancakes? Too sweet, overhyped. Love red velvet, but with chocolate chips and icing, it's too much. Buttermilk pancakes, now those are good. Nice and moist, perfect with butter and syrup. Got corned beef hash too, it was solid, but the potatoes were nothing special."

"I checked out the Casino, since I was crashin' at the Palazzo next door. Had high hopes, but it was packed with foreigners takin' pics and movin' slow. Found one slot game I dug, but some dude's fam took up all the other machines and they weren't even playin'. Wanted to hit the tables, but too many folks millin' around. Might stop by again, though. Had a decent vibe."

"Been here thrice. Twice through the drive-thru, once inside. Glad I did. Cook, stawky white guy, no gloves. He hits my chair, elbow on the way to the john, no words. I go, no paper towels. Use the blower, loud as hell. Means he didn't wash his hands. Walk out, he's got a handful of bacon. My friend, bacon burger. Oh, and his crack's showin' when he bends over. Good burgers and fries, but not worth his presence."

"Pink's in So Cal, I'd heard about it. Always wanted to try it. Saw one in Vegas, got excited. Disappointment, at least. Mushroom swiss dog, six-fifty. Rubbery hot dog, not enough cheese. Moments of goodness, but few. Too many mushrooms, not enough cheese. Proportion, that's the key. Maybe next time, try something else. Heard their chili cheese dog's great."

"Amidst the throngs of taverns on Rose Street,
The Auld Hundred doth pale in comparison,
Its lack of flair and charm doth make it seem,
A humdrum offering, devoid of cheer.

But wait! The patrons, they do adore,
This steadfast, no-frills drinking den,
For in its simplicity, they find,
Comfort and familiarity, their friend.

The fare, though not the most refined,
Is plentiful and satisfying,
And the selection of ales, though small,
Doth quench the thirst of those who doth imbibe.

So, if thou seeketh a place to rest,
And savor a pint, or two, or three,
The Auld Hundred shall serve thee well,
In this, thy quest for conviviality."

"A bachelor party didst bring me to this place,
Where I have been before, with joy and grace.
The location, prime, doth please mine eyes,
Within walking distance to hotels of great prize.

A discount, fat and fair, didst they bestow,
For my friends' player points, in collective show.
Though not the newest, rooms were clean and neat,
And staff, with kindness, didst my needs greet.

Their sportsbook, a delight, didst I enjoy,
But dining, alas, didst I not employ.
A shame, indeed, for I wouldst have liked,
To taste their culinary skills, so bright.

Yet, for the price, I wouldst stay again,
Though superior hotels, in Las Vegas, remain."

"Staff's good, attentive. Brought the kids one night, got dinner. Predictable bar grub, fried and heavy, but not bad. Weeknight visit, musician playing, couldn't hear ourselves think. Loud, man. Giving three stars 'cause of the service. Two stars otherwise, ain't no place for a date or family dinner. Good spot to catch a game or meet someone you don't wanna talk to."

"Food's alright. If you're in the neighborhood, grab a bite. But if you're hankerin' for real Chinese grub, head down to Spring Mountain or California. Had some killer Chinese in LA recently, so this place didn't quite measure up. It's like Panda Express - decent, but not authentic."

"A year had passed since last I savored Papa John's delightful pies. A fortunate coincidence, indeed, that this establishment lay along my path homeward bound. A gift card of ten dollars, purchased for a mere five, didst entice me to partake in their delectable offerings. Alas, the large pizza, though but fourteen inches in diameter, didst satisfy my craving. The Spinach Alfredo, with its rich, creamy sauce, didst tantalize my taste buds. My sole disappointment lay in the absence of the butter sauce and pepporncini, once included in the pizza box. Yet, understanding the reason, I didst not let it deter my enjoyment. The service, though somewhat slow, didst not diminish my gratification. Two registers, alas, with but one attendant, didst cause a slight delay. Nonetheless, I wouldst stop here again, should the price be fair."

"Methinks I've seen this show twice now, once with mine own eyes and once with my dearest husband by my side. 'Tis a Cirque du Soleil production, but not like others of its kind. No, this one doth focus on the East, with swords and acrobatics aplenty. A tale doth unfold upon the stage, and wires doth assist the performers in their feats. Alas, the language and certain characters didst grate upon mine ears, like the Tarzan-like figure. Yet, methinks the show doth have its charms, such as the grand platform that doth move and shift. The final scene, with combat on the vertical wall, didst stir mine heart the most. Verily, the rest didst not captivate me as other shows have done."

"Hark! A cafe most fair and bright,
Where one may work and dine with delight.
Their wifi free and tables grand,
Didst make my heart sing and my thoughts expand.

Their menu, diverse and vast,
Didst offer two salads, both to my taste.
One with vegetables and mustard, the other,
With oriental flavors, a true feast for my brother.

Their hot dishes and daily specials,
Didst change regularly, as the wind doth blow.
And though their prices, not too dear,
I didst find their coffee, quite beyond compare.

So if thou seekst a place to work or dine,
This cafe, most worthy, doth shine.
And should thou need, a bit of coin,
An ATM, nearby, doth dispense, with ease, I do declare."

"Upon a Friday eve, we dined at this place,
Eight lads, with reservation, did grace,
But late it was, and outside we did sit,
In heat that did our patience soon quit.
The meatballs, kobe, were quite divine,
My filet, eight ounces, lacked a fine vine,
Asparagus, a heaping portion, did please,
But other dishes, pasta, did not tease.
Service was good, no mistakes did they make,
Pricey, but not too much, for a steak.
Yet, underwhelmed, I must confess,
For more, I would pay, or less, I would guess."

"I chanced upon this eatery, with naught but two score dollars in my purse, to sample their so-called 'fish sandwiches' and a'side salad' of dubious quality. Alas, the bread did swallow up the fish, like a maiden fair devoured by love's sweet passion, leaving naught but a mediocre taste upon my lips. And the salad? Fie upon it! A paltry mix of iceberg, unworthy of a second glance. Yet, the service, kind sir, was most excellent, as if the very heavens themselves had sent forth an angel to attend to mine every need. The establishment, in its finery, didst please mine eyes, yet, alas, the victuals did not merit a second visit."

"Good eatin' and good drinkin'. Pasta on point, just like they said. Asked the waiter about the wine, he knew his stuff. Ended up with more than just a snack. Classy joint, nice people, damn good food."

"A venti green tea lemonade, I didst pay,
And in return, a tall one didst play.
The reason why I didst not go back,
Was school, where I didst have to pack.
In haste, I didst depart, with naught but time,
To pine for those fair maidens, who didst take my rhyme."

"Verily, fair friends, I do declare,
In South Phoenix, there be a place most rare,
Where donuts, sweet and fluffy, doth abound,
And make our toilsome labors seem less profound.

The maple bar, oh how it doth delight,
With flavors rich and sugars soft and bright,
It maketh all our cares and woes fade away,
Like mist before the rising sun's ray.

So, friends, if thou find thyself in need,
Of sustenance, or comfort, or good deed,
Seek out this haven, 'twill not disappoint,
For in its depths, thy hunger shall be blessed."

"This joint's got one thing goin' for it - their bread. It's got character, ya know? Unique look, texture, and taste. Rest of the menu's pretty meh, overpriced too. Small sandwiches costin' five, six bucks? Nuh-uh. Service ain't great either, few people workin', cashier gets antsy when you're takin' your time. Drive-thru's my go-to now. Building's old, parkin's a pain, but I still come back for that bread. Get the small original, it's decent. But honestly, if they switched to regular bread, I wouldn't bother."

"Front cafe's got fresh-baked white cookies for five bucks. Damn good deal. Inside, the restaurant's got long waits and water refills that'll drive you mad. Skip the Sunday pasta, it'll ruin your gut. Stick to the cookies, they're worth every penny."

"Fare fit for kings, yet somethings amiss, methinks. 'Twas passable, no more, no less, and noise of gamers did not vex. Seated swiftly, sans reservation, in busy din. Menu, brief but diverse, doth offer choices fine. Prime steak panini, with tangy sauce, did please, and potato salad, rich, with just enough mayonnaise. Alas, poor service doth mar the experience. Slow, with long wait for check, and credit card, didst tarry. Server, scarce seen, did leave much to be desired."
"Beet salad, fantastic. Service, new but clumsy. Spilled water on my table mid-meal. Short rib loco moco, too salty."

"3.5 stars. Went with friends for the open bar. Cover was steep, bouncers were rude. TAO looks sharp. Made me hungry walking through the restaurant. Got there early, no issues with space. Main goal was drinks, didn't explore other dance floors. Basic well drinks were off, waited too long for drinks. Felt good leaving, music was alright. Didn't know Dash Berlin was playing, good thing we left before it got packed. Danced with plenty of space. Not a bad time at TAO, but need another visit to explore."

"Hark! I came to this place with great expectations,
After reading many a glowing review, I must confess.
But alas, my hopes were soon dashed,
For what I found was naught but a humble hash.

My burger, oh how dry it was,
The cook did press and press, alack!
I did cry out in my mind,
"Please, stop! Forsooth, have mercy, kind sir!"

The fries, they were but meh,
Crunchy, yet lacking in flavor, I do declare.
But the ingredients, fresh they were,
A redeeming quality, beyond compare.

The patties, preformed they were,
Not frozen, a plus, I must aver.
And bacon, plenty there was,
In each bite, a savory treat, 'twas.

The lettuce, green and crisp,
A pleasant surprise, I must admit.
But alas, the price, too steep,
For what I got, my wallet did weep.

So, to this place, I shall not return,
Unless, perchance, I lived nearby, and then,
Perhaps, I might, for a quick bite,
But nay, not worth the price, I do declare, good night."

"Hark, good sir or madam, seek thou a place to dine
In North Scottsdale, where gyros be divine?
'Tis a spot most wondrous, with staff so kind
And speedy service, thy hunger to unwind.

The cost, betwixt seven and ten, a fair price to pay
For a meal most satisfying, come what may.
In North Scottsdale, this place doth stand apart
A haven for thy taste buds, a work of art."

"Chinese food here ain't half bad. Had some decent grub in the past, maybe that's why this place didn't impress me much. Egg rolls too salty, hot and sour soup not sour enough, veggie pork bland. Not a fan of over-seasoning. Place is quick and affordable though, might give it another shot."

"Grampa's Pizzeria - a name that fits like a glove.

No one makes pizza like Gramps. It's delicious, through and through. Quality ingredients, flavors that pop. I love Gramps and his pizza, simple as that.

But my last visit had me wondering if the old man's losing his touch. The host gave us a funny look, like we were strangers in his house. Should've known something was up. Appetizer comes out, it's cold as ice. I ask, "You forget to cook this?" They poke it, shrug, and toss it back in the oven.

Then, the pizza. Don't know what happened, but our server says it'll be a while. Free beer for the wait, courtesy of Gramps. Generous to a fault, that one.

Place was dead, three couples tops. Good thing, too. Busy Monday would've sent Gramps into a tizzy."

"Ay, 'tis been a goodly while since last I had mine eyes checked,
And when I did, 'twas but a cursory glance,
To gain my driver's license, or peer into a machine,
And say what I saw, without much further ado.

But now, my dearest Denise doth need her eyes checked,
And thus, I too must suffer this fate,
To prove that mine own peepers still do function,
And are not, as yet, beyond redemption's gate.

The Christenbury Eye Center, a place most professional,
With rooms aplenty, where they doth perform their wondrous feats,
To test mine eyes, and see if they be working aright,
Or if they merely pretend, to ease my troubled mind.

They seem to know their craft, with famous folk on display,
Who swear they know their business, come what may,
And offer, too, the chance to rectify mine sight,
With laser surgery, a cure most swift and bright.

But alack! They gave me drops to dilate mine eyes,
Which made my vision blur, and caused me such surprise,
Yet still they said my eyes were sound, and in good health,
So I shall hope to avoid their care, for some time hence."

Last night, went there for the first time. Took ages to get in. Some joker started a scrap with us 'cause they didn't like us parked next to 'em. Couldn't hear parts of the flick 'cause of the racket from the neighborin' movie. Helicopters flyin' around, real distractin'. But hey, prices were decent for tickets, plus we had coupons. Not bad.

"Airports ain't for the faint of heart. Morning and afternoon flights, especially. Folks getting on those planes, they're usually feeling pretty rough. Hungover, you know? Like they've been put through a wringer. And the airport itself, it don't help none. It's loud, it's bright, it's a real sensory assault. Makes you wonder who thought this was a good idea."
"Good eatery. Menu, top-notch. Service, spotty. Atmosphere, lackin' juice. Grub, decent. Grits and pork belly, my jam. Quality, high. Pricey, yeah."

Upon an eve, accompanied by my noble son, we ventured into a humble abode to partake in a slice of sustenance - a bountiful portion of pizza adorned with lavish toppings. Verily, it possessed a slight sheen of grease, perchance owed to the pepperoni's indulgence. Yet, in sum, its quality prevailed. The repast swiftly graced our table, prompting thoughts of returning anon to sample diverse fare. Alas, a lamentable absence - no fountain libations! This omission, to my mind, cast a shadow of dissatisfaction.
"Meatballs, man. They make up for the crap service. Terrace, Strip view, perfect weather. Fun."

Upon the twenty-eighth day of the sixth month in the year of our Lord, two thousand and twelve, I partook in libations and partook of pizza within this establishment's walls.

'Twas a Thursday, wherefore this place overflowed with throngs and tumult! 'Twas scarce an inch to claim as mine own, lacking in seclusion, amidst a cacophony that filled the air.

The attendants rendered service with utmost excellence, yet the fare, ah! exorbitant for its offerings. The thin-crust, albeit flavorsome, arrived overcooked, a crispness and crunch abound. Such preparation, a preference diverse among patrons.

Yet, a grievance most dire: the privy, a diminutive chamber fit for a single soul, a concept incongruous with the multitude this venue did entertain. Anticipate a delay should nature's call bid thee entry.

Perchance I shall return, or mayhap not.

Verily, though I lack expertise in discerning authentic Korean fare, I am an admirer of all well-fashioned Asian culinary creations. 

 Amidst unassuming adornments, swift attendants graced our presence (we, perchance, the second table). The company chose the Korean BBQ ribs, whilst I partook in the dolsot, if memory serves me well. The meat, anointed in grease and fat, cloaked in a delicate, sugared sauce - true to its essence. The dolsot, a spectacle in a mighty stone vessel ablaze, beseeched one to blend rice, vegetables, and meat with a spoon, rendering a crispy warmth. An offering lacking in fervor, yet a novel experience. 

 The accompaniments, though not overly inspired, held merit. Who would have fathomed Koreans relishing apples and mayonnaise akin to my Midwest upbringing? A sweetness juxtaposed with the fiery kimchee! 

 A commendable choice in downtown Chandler, forsooth, should one seek to venture beyond conventional confines.
"Good grub, but the fuku burger fell short. Overpriced for what you get. Not impressed with the patty or the fixin's. Togarashi fries? Meh. It's in a neat food court though."

"Five-star service, bread with olive paste, not bad. Calamari? Bland, too salty. Pesto gnocchi? Mediocre, like Chef Boyardee with green sauce. Steak? Way too much pepper, Alfredo sauce for pasta? Olive Garden looks like Ruth's Chris. Dessert? Good. Bread and dessert, yes. Food? Heck no."

Upon yestereve, I ventured to this abode to witness a postseason match among fellow Yelpers. Verily, the array of screens rendered no seat unblest by a view. For those who abhor smoke, a haven beckons through the non-smoking portal at the rear, yet to access the Men's room or partake in billiards, one must traverse the smoking patio's ordeal. As for the Men's room, while I've witnessed fouler chambers, this one languished in neglect, pleading for a mop, for my soles adhered to the floor by the urinal. 

 Libations flowed aplenty, with a cornucopia of beers on draught. Intent on a burger, I found the table inundated with sundry fare. The nachos proved middling, and though no fan of fiery wings, these grilled morsels left a lingering warmth, surprisingly pleasing. An onion ring, potato skin, and cheese stick graced my palate, embodying solid bar fare without eliciting awe. 

 Service, a mercurial dance betwixt excellence and disappearance, amidst shortages of iced tea, brownies, and select brews. Yet, those imbibing water among the drinkers faced no interrogation. 

 In sum, a stalwart bastion in our neighborhood, this establishment stood as a commendable haven for revelry and repast.

"Pizza delivered to hotel. Box opened, pie looked good. Ingredients as requested. Cut in squares, like a true Chicago pie. Epic fail, though. Can't pick up a slice with all ingredients on top. Three of us, two never had Chicago style thin crust. No cutlery, mess ensued. Hand-pulled empty slices, tried putting ingredients on each slice. Gave up. If can't cut pie, create crappy experience. 3 stars for fresh ingredients, great sauce, owner added Giardiniera. Minus 2 stars for mess. Had higher hopes."

In bygone days, this abode impressed my senses greatly. Yet, my recent sojourn hath diminished a five-star commendation to a meager three. This buffet, ensconced in the Parisian walls, lacks the extraordinary. Its expanse, a trifle short, fails to captivate. I recall an abundance of piscine fare, a realm I care little for. \n\n On a Sunday's eve, the queue stretched an hour long! A wait not befitting its recompense. Verily, it is not worth such ado!

"Lemongrass, a joint that typifies the grub game my missus and I often face on holiday. Thai chow, mediocre at best. Spring rolls, frozen and flavorless, veggies mushy. Pho, cinnamon-heavy. Singapore Noodles, spicy and decent, but not worth the wait. Service? Forget about it. Don't bother booking a table; try somewhere else."

Marry, I find it surprising that Betty Lou garners scarce reviews. We partook in the Monona brunch cruise and found favor in it.

In sum, the affair boasts sweetness, yet confess, ample room for betterment remains.

Foremost among the grievances: the worth for the coin, the scant selection of seats upon the vessel, and the dearth of crew's attendance.

Yet, amidst these woes, stand virtues: the delectation and abundance of victuals, the boat's fine ambiance.

'Twas disheartening to be jostled by a brood of youthful souls, who claimed the seats atop. Arrive early, station thyself afore the wooden dock where they embark. A more orderly procession, in the sequence of bookings, would improve matters.

The feast, a marvel! Appetizers, main course, and dessert, laid out with perfection, a delight to partake.

Mimosas, albeit flavorful, faltered in strength. Two attendants struggled to serve fifty souls, making it arduous to secure their attention. Dismissal for sustenance transpired not as expected.

The vistas, picturesque! The captain, in a swift turn, affords glimpses for snapshots against the Capitol and Monona Terrace backdrop.

"Love this joint, but feel outta place. Twenty years too young, maybe? Dig the tunes, though - real music. Can't tell if I'm young with good taste or if everyone else here's older. Showed up on a Friday, Baddness played. Funky vibes, no blues. Seemed like something straight outta Mystery Train. Red suits, sequined coat - badass. A+ for music and style. Not sure 'bout this place being a blues house, though. Rhythm Room's more my speed. Feel like I shoulda been born twenty years earlier."

I must play the spoilsport and confess my visit was middling. Both my brother and I dined here, leaving our repast unfinished. Perchance... our hunger failed us. 

 Yet, perchance, my palate lacks the wisdom to discern true Asian fare? Or did misfortune grace our plates? We arrived in haste ere the closing hour, a plight that seldom pleases the cooks. 

 The proprietor, however, exuded extraordinary kindness. His demeanor, remarkably serene, left us pondering, "Could any soul be more tranquil?" Indeed, I've encountered none so peaceful. 

 Being strangers to this realm, the owner presented a pictorial menu, a boon for our unacquainted minds. 

 That being said, would I return? Hardly, unless mere proximity beckoned and another soul sought the path.

"I'd passed by that restaurant plenty of times before, and it always gave me a warm, welcoming feel. I told myself I'd stop in one day, and I finally did. The service was good, but the grub wasn't worth the scratch. It was overpriced, like something off the tourist menu. Tofu Hut has better options for less dough. If the food was as good as the joint looked, I'd have given 'em another star. But it was just alright."
The food is tasty, but so much MSG!  I'm usually not very sensitive to MSG, but man you can really feel it after you eat here!

"Hark! What madness doth possess these folk,
To clutch their stuffed beasts with such fondness?
A token, perchance, for their orders taken,
To guide the food to its intended place?

I, in mine ignorance, didst decline
The offer of the foul, plush creature.
And thus, my meal didst never arrive,
Leaving me in hunger's bitter grasp.

Chuy's doth bring to mind those coastal eateries,
Where surf and turf do meet in harmony.
Their menu, vast and varied, doth boast
Of flavors bold, yet lacking in spice.

A platter of whitefish tacos, I didst choose,
With shrimp skewers, too, for good measure.
The latter, sprinkled with lemon and heat,
Didst make a meal most satisfying, indeed.

The fish, alas, didst not taste fresh,
Nor knew I what whitefish doth imply.
Rice, beans, and cabbage salad, all standard,
But the last, in truth, didst need some aid.

Though unimpressed, I may return anon,
To sample their margaritas, a bargain at two.
Now that, my friends, doth sound most tempting!"

"Hark! What woe is this? Alack, I did forget To rate this place, where I did dine and sip. 'Twas mid-day, hot as blazes, and I did wait To be seated, some twenty minutes or more, alack! The food, it was good, huge portions, I did find, And split my sandwich, "The strip steak," I did design. Good, but a better cut of steak, I would have liked, e'er so. Overpriced, methought, but still, 'twas all quite good. If weather had permitted, I would have preferred Outside seating, and dessert, but full and hot, I did feel, and so, I did not partake. But, lo! The next day, I did return, and tried The frozen hot chocolate, and Oreo, frozen hot, At the walk-up window, fast and convenient, by my troth! Both were good, but Oreo, richer, and better, I did find. The plain, somewhat iced down, and not so big, I did observe. A chocolate lover, I, and so, I did post Some pics, for all to see, of the items, and such. And thus, I shall return, to this place, anon, And to the one in New York, I shall make haste, To compare, and see, the difference, and the taste."
"Dollar underwear. Ten-dollar bras. Hell yeah, I'm in. *Only in sale section, and good luck finding your size."

"Tacos, simple street style, like 'em. Al pastor, asada, both tasty. Al pastor, nice spice. Green tamale, gross. Masa, barely any cheese or green chile. Can't find good tamales around here. Jamaica to drink, wished I got horchata instead. Watered down, sour. Come for tacos, skip rest."

In fair Las Vegas, I do sojourn twice a year,
And at diverse casinos, my abode doth vary.
This last September, at Excalibur I did reside,
A place we've visited ere, where we do take pride.
The chambers be clean, the bedding soft and neat,
The cost, quite reasonable, doth make our feet meet.
We did leave a gratuity for the maiden fair,
Who tidied our room with diligence and care.
She penned a note of thanks, a gesture most kind,
A first, from any, for a token left behind.
Her name was Clementine, and her work did shine,
A credit to her craft, a gem, a true find.

"Costco ain't all it's cracked up to be. Parking's a bitch, but that's standard. Samples are the real draw for me, but this joint's got subpar offerings. Slow service, constant shortages, and inefficient replenishment. Other Costcos do it better. \n\nBut hey, I still dig the beer and wine selection. And those discount restaurant cards are clutch. Just don't expect me to be all smiles when the sample situation's lacking."

"Tasty pizza, unique style, three stars. But slow service, no slices, no lunch special. Industrial area customers need quick turnaround, 20 minutes max. Get it together, guys. Add slices, a slice and a drink deal. Basic stuff, common at other pizza joints. Would appreciate the opportunity to enjoy your pizza more often, with reasonable time and price." (298 tokens)

"We found this joint and decided to grab some grub. Had the hummus and chips, onion rings, fries. It was all good. Service was decent until it got slow, then it was like they forgot about us. I tried to flag someone down, but they just ignored me."

"Dropped in for dinner with friends. Hadn't tried the BBQ yet, so I split the big boy plate with my girl. All the BBQ was good, but the chicken was a bit dry. Pullled pork was decent, though. Place has a dated vibe, but who cares? Feels like a neighborhood joint. Service was top-notch. Problem is, there's better BBQ in Charlotte. This spot's easy to miss."

"Hark! What fortune brings thee here, my friend?
A tale of inspiration, strange and true,
Of how the soft serve machine came to be,
From a most unlikely source, 'twas born.

As I walked my loyal hound, Toots, one day,
He stopped and did his business on the lawn,
Of Ed and Dolores Feinstein, much to their dismay.
Their wrath was great, and I did fear,
For Ed, an attorney, vowed to bring us to justice.
But from this mess, a spark of creativity,
Didst strike my mind, and thus, the machine was born.

I wished to create a device that could,
Pinch off the ice cream, clean and neat,
Unlike Toots, who left a trail unsightly,
And so, my friend, the soft serve machine,
Was fashioned, thanks to Toots's uncouth feat.

Now, as I serve this frozen treat,
I cannot help but laugh at the absurdity,
Of how this machine, a replica of my dog,
Doth bring joy to all who taste its sweetness.

So here's to Toots, whose mischief and glee,
Inspired this marvel of technology,
May his memory live on, forevermore,
In the soft serve machine, a testament to his lore."

"Galaxy? Nah, not worth it. People who work there? Weirdos. Twice in one week, twice disappointed. Breakfast sandwiches? Alright, but overpriced. Coffee? Nothing special. Almond syrup, though. That's a plus. Star Wars decor? Cool, but not enough. Poor customer service ruins it."

"Hark! A stop for lunch, and lo, their specials beckon,
Miso soup, salad, sashimi, rice, a feast fit for a king.
The staff, friendly, doth attend with cheerful mien,
But, alas, the salad, wilted, doth offend mine eyes.
Bell peppers, chilis, yuck, a strange combination,
And rice, a-missing, doth leave mine appetite unsatisfied.
Four servants, confused, doth come to aid,
But service, disorganized, doth mar their zeal.
Asked if all be well, I speak of salad's woe,
